How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

I spent a total of 5 hours a week outside the classroom on this course, broken down as such:

Textbook Homework (weekly average) - 2 hours
SAS Code Homework - 2 hours
Textbook review - 1 hours

It truly varied - weeks when a problem set was due, I probably spent 15+ hours on assignments. For the midterm and final, I put in about 20 hours each to review and re-write notes. Otherwise, maybe 1 - 3 hours a week (on weeks where nothing was due or scheduled).

One suggestion for this class is that there should be a compendium of sorts (or like a binded folder) given out in the beginning of the course with all the printouts we will use throughout the course. This would help keep all of the sas codes we used throughout the semester organized.I felt that riffling through all the handouts was a challenge and it would also make it easier for the professor as well if she didn't have to print out copies before each class. Instead just have a booklet of all of them that students bring with them to class each day. I think going over the slide deck in lab wasted time. The homework before lab should be to review the slide deck and then you could have the entire lab period to do that lab work and ask questions.

Strengths: I thought the workload was very fair, and Dr. Claus is great at addressing any confusion or questions. There was plenty of help available outside of class for both class material and SAS-related questions. 

Weaknesses: the notes were sometimes scattered and hard to follow along during lecture. The grading system was confusing as well-- I feel like the amount of points taken off for questions either in the homework or exams was a bit arbitrary. Points would often be taken off with no real explanation as to why, so I don't know how to improve upon them in the future.

Overall, I thought the course was okay but could have been taught better. I really enjoyed the teaching methods of the guest lecturer.

The quality of the TFs varied.  Some seemed more engaged and willing to teach than others.
I do not like the format of lab write up. We should include output and discuss them more thoroughly. This way we can pinpoint where mistakes were made and get stronger feedback

Strengths:  relevance to the field of public health, relevance to epidemiology when taken concurrently

Weaknesses:  coding assignments teach how to complete the assignment, they do not teach how to become proficient in SAS
Good class need consistent teaching amongst TA but way too hard of an exam. Please curve!! even open book/notes means nothing

The material was interesting. For an intro level course, there were some fascinating applications in the problem sets and material that went more in-depth compared to previous statistics courses I have taken (not at Yale). 

However, the structure of the course was severely lacking. For one, I felt like we did not "learn" SAS; rather, we learned how to copy code. Coding is all about problem-solving and tinkering, but I felt like that element was completely missing in the course. Additionally, despite R being an option, nobody opted to use it. Even though I wanted to, there was little to no support to guide someone, so I felt compelled to just use SAS, even though companies are straying away from it more. The lab slides dedicated maybe 1 slide for the R code and 15 or so for SAS.

Second, the classes themselves did not help enhance my understanding of the material. It was nearly impossible to read the instructor's handwriting in the notes, so you really had to pay close attention (which is a good thing, of course). However, the pacing was hard to follow, which caused a great deal of confusion. If we do chi squared test problems in the problem set which is due today, why are we learning about the chi squared test on the day it is due? I sensed many people had a hard time following along, both during class and the exam reviews.
I think this course does a really good job with teaching through problem sets and lab assignments. The practical aspect of the class helped me learn a lot more than if I were to just sit in lecture.

Learned very useful skills (like SAS) and statistical analysis methods that are incredibly applicable to the field of research in public health. Skills from this class helped me get a paid summer internship as a data scientist!

I would recommend creating a compendium of all of the SAS printouts that were given out throughout the semester. If each student was given a compiled folder or book with the pages in order of when we were going to discuss them that we could bring to and from class each day, it would save the professor a lot of time to print out the handouts before each class and would help the students stay organized instead of rifling through all the handouts. Also I think the homework before lab should have been to review the slide deck because when the TF went through it in the beginning of lab it wasted about 20 min of time that we could have been working on the lab.

Things could have been explained more sequentially in class and more steps could have been shown for better comprehension. Also, more effort on the part of the professor to make sure everyone can ready the notes on the board (very sloppy handwriting).

Class notes are not very clear, sometimes it is very hard to read the handwritings. may be better to present the content in the form of powerpoint. 

The slides for sas labs were very clear and good for review.
The strength of the course is definitely in learning SAS. That being said, we really don't learn R at all, in fact it's barely mentioned.
The lab sections were not conducive to my learning, the teaching fellows were not helpful.

In general, I enjoyed this course. Some of the earlier material was review for me. I think the emphasis on SAS was important for me as it was the first statistical programming language I have learned. I do wish R was better incorporated into the class as I feel I mostly needed to teach myself it. The presentation of material could be slightly more organized.
disconnect between teaching and what is expected to learn
difficult subject not friendly for students who don't have a quantitative mind

The way SAS was taught was incredibly poorly organized.  We were never really taught how to do anything in SAS and then expected to somehow know how to do things.  It seemed like an afterthought of the class.  The SAS portion of the course should definitely have been a separate course.  I learned virtually nothing about how to do do work in SAS and simply copied what was in the powerpoints without really knowing what it meant.
good

I found the labs to be helpful and mostly straight forward. Homework assignments were also fair for what was taught in class, but there were times when homework would be due a day or two after material was covered in lecture. This was a bit stressful, and didn't allow a lot of time to comprehend material nor ask questions with TF office hours. I did find that it was super beneficial to attend office hours prior to homework and labs being due as there were a lot of things covered. Lectures were an adequate level. Material wasn't always presented in the most organized fashion, but paired nicely with the textbook.

I appreciated how organized and straightforward the expectations for this class were. I also enjoyed having SAS lab in order to apply what we learned in lecture. I did find it difficult to make up for a missed lecture simply by looking at the photocopied notes on Canvas. I also felt like the expectations for some labs and exams weren't fully clear, which resulted in points being taken away.

Strengths:
+ Taught very necessary information for a career in public health
+ Learned some SAS skills

Weaknesses:
- Very little emphasis on learning R
- Final during reading period
- Professor wrote on clear projector paper with permanent marker
- Sometimes the book was better at explaining the topic than the class notes

The grading of the homework and tests seems arbitrary. Losing 8 points for leaving out a buzzword and only losing 1 for a serious arithmetic error. Kind of gave the sense that the points don't matter at all.

Strengths: The TFs, the professor's expertise in seeing how student's saw how to solve problems and switching it to our lens. Also, repetition was good.
Weaknesses: I did not appreciate how the final was not reflective of our practice exam. I thought the midterm was fairly written but the final was pretty out of the ball-park. I also wish the professor wrote with smaller pens on the projector because it is terribly difficult deciphering her handwriting.

Strengths: I really enjoyed what we learned. The course did a nice job of laying out the foundations of Biostats. (I previously took a Biostats course in undergrad and wanted to compare how the two were taught. I thought this one was very clear.) Also, office hours were really helpful and plentiful, and homework was given back in a very timely manner.
Weaknesses: The tests sometimes covered examples that were merely covered in class rather than in homework. It would have been nice to go further into some test questions in our homework.
Improvement: Having the tests focus more/expand on homework material rather than random examples done in class that we never discussed again.

strengths- clear notes during class with clear explanations for questions

weaknesses- perhaps provide typed up notes of the lecture notes so that it is legible

I really loved this class, instructor is very clear and articulate!! I  But I think adding SAS into the class is a little bit too much! I would like to take 2 separate classes and to learn SAS (programming/data analysis) deeper instead tapping the pond with very little inapplicable knowledge (because my skill is not ready) and forget about everything I've learned later.. I understand it's introductory, but programming and stats nowadays are so important and we didn't focus on maths part enough!!!

I learned a lot in this class, even though I had taken a similar statistics course in undergrad. My only complaint was that sometimes lectures did not seem to have a flow--Dr. Claus would go on tangents sometimes with other problems and that got a little confusing. Also, I know Dr. Claus has worked on this, but sometimes her reading was soooo hard to read.

Professor Claus is a great teacher and she made her biostats lectures interesting by including different data sets that applied to the class. There was a lot of emphasis on SAS which is a useful quantitative skill.

Good for an intro-level course
Exams are open-book and open-note, so no need for memorization 
Fairly good at integrating by-hand math and SAS/R

This course was slightly disjointed in my opinion. I had trouble following the flow of material that was presented in class. More clearly defining the topic of each class would be helpful. The SAS portion of the class was relatively well laid out. I felt that I was able to learn basic commands, but at times I also felt as though I was just copying what was available in the examples. I was satisfied with the level application this course demonstrated. Problems were very relevant to public health and almost no statistical concept was presented without a direct application.

I thought the lecture portion of this class was excellent- I really appreciated that she did not use lecture slides but instead hand-wrote and explained everything as she went. The abundance of examples used also contributed to a greater understanding of content and how it can be applied to practice problems.

Strengths: the open book open notes exams
Weaknesses: the teaching ability of the professor
The class content and the instructor's teaching style is good, but the notes uploaded on Canvas can be more readable in case sometimes we are not able to attend the class.
It would be more helpful to have more lab time and less lecture time, or to do part of lecture in the lab room so that students can use SAS while the professor is teaching it

Overall, I learned a great deal from this course. The level of material was fair. I believe the weighting system of the grades should be shifted to increase the weight on the homeworks as a significant amount of time was spent on these assignments. I also think the timing was somewhat off, where we would have homework problems assigned and due prior to learning the material or learning the material the day it was due, which was frustrating at times.
I liked how this class incorporated SAS into whatever topic we were learning about.  I feel as though I got two classes in one.

I really enjoyed the challenge of the course, and took advantages of all the resources that it offered throughout the semester (lecture, office hours (prof & TF), labs). While I liked the way that the class was taught thematically, and especially appreciated the integration of more tangible examples towards the end of the semester, I think it would have been really helpful to have slides or some type of outline of class to look back on. While the slides that Dr. Claus provides and takes notes on are helpful for recording/remembering many aspects of what we learned in class, sometimes it was a little challenging to locate something I wanted to go back and review. Despite struggling a lot in this class in the beginning, I found it to be a positive experience ultimately, and I learned so much--I do feel like I have a real foundation in statistics from which I can build!

I felt that this course was an adequate introduction to basic principles in statistics and did a good job of teaching those concepts in relation to their public health applications.  Doing the reading before lecture is necessary to reinforce concepts.

I would have liked a stronger emphasis on SAS. I understand that we need to understand statistical concepts but having to do problems by hand isn't very relevant to our future careers. I found it frustrating that students who were not enrolled in the course could attend computer labs- the classroom was too large and I would show up early only to be stuck way in the back, where I could not read the board and the TF could not see me raising my hand.
It could have been more rigorous in teaching students how statistical methods are conceptualized.

STRENGTHS: Really nice professor, applicable class, liked that we were learning what we were doing by hand and computer, liked how the tests reflected us being able to reference books and info in the real world
WEAKNESSES:The notes are very difficult to read, there's a lot of jumping around in lecture material, switching between SAS and R at the beginning of the lecture was confusing, the final wasn't like what she stated (many SAS printouts)

it is a basic class for new students to understand the statistical knowledge. the recommended boos are really useful. But I think to use PPT while teaching is easier for students to understand the class content. it is clearer than hand-writing and easier for reviewing.

The class is nice in that it doesn't require you to memorize any information. Tests are open note, open book, so it's more about whether you understand the material. So many handouts, so compiling notes was a bit difficult. In addition, tests were difficult, even though they were open note. The questions were a bit confusing to avoid asking in the exact same wording as in other assignments. In addition, grading seemed fairly subjective.

It would be useful to record these lectures like other courses in YSPH are recorded.  It would be very useful to see an equation used again while studying.  Sometimes, it can be difficult to write down all of the information presented plus notes in class.  While learning how to work with equations, many of us would benefit from the ability to re-watch lectures.

The course fulfilled its objective of presenting and teaching the main concepts and principles of biostatistics. The course relies on some degree of self-learning, especially for labs. It was interesting to learn and overview the concepts for SAS.

The coursework is very relevant and the syllabus does a very good work to explain the requirements at the outset.

The homework assignments are also well designed. But biostatistics is a hard subject to teach and it is hard to satisfy the students on as far as the outcome/productivity of attending a lecture is concerned. But I am sure that it is something that the teaching staff is aware of already.

Overall, I am satisfied with the resources that were provided as a part of this course.
Nonegreat course!

The lab practice is good for someone just started to learn programming, especially that it is closely connected with the course. 
I sincerely hope Powerpoint could be used instead of handwriting. It is not easy to read the notes after the class for review purpose.

I thought it was good. I think that at times, the professor had trouble answering questions in class, but overall it was a good course. I would say that there were times where the difficulty and question format course work did not align with examinations, which made preparations challenging.

Strengths = It covered a lot of the foundational material in addition to learning about SAS in the lab course. It was organized well.

Weaknesses = Sometimes labs were extremely easy, while other times it was very difficult. Sometimes I felt like the answers were just being given to us, which wasn't horrible since I still learned a lot about SAS through that way without experiencing a lot of frustration.
It was helpful. I would have liked more focus on R.

The explanation of content in the course was very difficult for me as a student who has not taken a math course since high school. The professor was clearly brilliant - so much so that at times I think she overestimated her students' ability to grasp complex concepts. Some of us are not very good at this and would have benefitted from a slower, more basic approach. However, the tone of the course was friendly and approachable, the professor was extremely supportive of the students, and the teaching assistants and office hours were very very helpful.

I also noticed that the TFs seemed overburdened in the labs. Our TF was constantly running around the room to answer questions from students, as there were so many students in our computer lab that she never had time to answer all of our questions in the time provided. I would have gotten more out of the labs if there had been more sections of lab - Lily was so incredibly helpful to my understanding of the content, and I would have learned more if there had been a smaller number of students.
The course is excellent and it is useful especially for students who do not have any background of it. The homework can really help with remembering and understanding the topic.

Strengths: covers a lot of necessary and great material. Covers the theory and math behind statistics as well as through programs like SAS. Weaknesses: not enough examples done in class or in homework to get a firm grasp on the concept. I found that I would get certain concepts and theories confused if both covered at the same time in class, this would result in using the incorrect theory to a question and without further examples I wouldn't be able to know this until the assignment was given back to me.
Course material is highly applicable to public health and medical fields. However, class size is too big and therefore lectures should be recorded.

I think the lectures could have been organized more efficiently with powerpoint slides. We had a PhD student, Yazmin, come in and teach the class using clear step by step instructions. These days were the most helpful for me. It was really tough following along with the projector, and referring back to the notes on Canvas was tough because the handwriting was difficult to discern. For a student like myself who didn't come from any sort of math background, it was really tough for me to grasp the material in this class with this type of instruction.

Overall, I learned a lot from this course and, having never taken biostatistics before, feel as though I gained new and useful skills for my career. Often, it seemed, however, the material we covered in lecture was much easier than what was covered in the homework assignments and in the book - I wish there was more interaction/bridging between the lectures and the book material, which I did see briefly at the end of the course. 

I did wish there were more TFs in this class because it seemed like the lab sections were too large for one person to manage, at least in my experience.

Strengths 
- The textbook is great and you really do come out with a solid basic understanding of biostatistics and the SAS program. 

Weaknesses 
- Professor Claus is pretty disorganized and her in-class notes are impossible to read or make sense of afterward. 
- I wish the organization of files on canvas was easier to follow. The file naming system needs major work.
- The grades for assignments really should be posted on canvas as part of standard protocol so that students can track their progress and grade instead of just making guesses.
A lot of work between homework assignments and lab

Strengths - comprehensive, introductory overview to biostatistics. Kind and friendly TFs. 
Weaknesses - notes were a bit unorganized in class - difficult to follow along (although Prof. Claus's reviews for the midterm and final were extraordinarily helpful - I wish she had 'centered' us on the material throughout the course). She also told us that we wouldn't have to know how to do things that showed up on the final exam...
N/A Placed out
It can help you build up your statistical thinking.

The course was a fantastic introduction to the study of biostatistics. Progression was quick but never too quick, and lectures, if you attended, always flowed logically. The tests were fair. Homework and labs were challenging and rewarding. Most importantly, I felt that I learned a great deal of material, and that I learned it well.
This course is very useful in the future study.

It is evident how much Dr. Clause cares about the subject material and her students. However, going to class was hindered by the fact that her writing is completely ineligible. While I understand that Biostatistics is something that needs to be written out to understand the steps, it was nearly impossible to decode the board.

Strengths are that it was very applicable and skills are transferable
Weaknesses: the textbook was sometimes impossible to understand. It would use referent nouns too often, then it wasn't clear what they were referring to. This made it impossible to understand many sections. Also, I think the textbook don't take enough time to explain all concepts. I felt that even with reading it before and after class I could not understand at all what it was saying way too often. Also, when points were taken off, I wish a small explanation was written. I couldn't figure out on my own what was wrong, as I can in my other classes.

Strengths are the back to basics learning, clear and open-book
weaknesses: not much overlap with SAS so felt like two classes
Use slides instead of the overhead projector.
I was exempted from taking this course.

STRENGTHS
-- Assignments were prepared in advance and presented in the syllabus at the start of term, so students had the opportunity to plan ahead and work at a measured pace, in congruence with individual schedules.
-- Class material and computer labs balanced each other nicely.
-- Expectations of how to complete coursework were clear, and exams were open-book, allowing students to demonstrate knowledge of concepts.
WEAKNESSES
-- Although writing live on a projector may be more engaging for the writer, it was essentially a less-legible PowerPoint for us students. I would have benefited from a legit PowerPoint instead. Handwriting could theoretically be useful for answering student questions, but that was not how it was used in this course.
-- There was not enough engagement with students during class. I recommend 5-10 minutes during class for students to work through questions in small groups, before sharing with the full class. Also, incorporate methods to gauge understanding of the material during the lesson, and adjust course accordingly (if 90% of students answer a question correctly through a polling/voting/handraising system, move on to a new subject; if 30% of students answer a question correctly, the educator has not effectively conveyed the concept and must backtrack, rephrase, explain, elicit questions from students).
The course content is important to a Public Health student. However, I felt as though the amount of coursework and homework/labs that were required seemed unreasonable at times.

- overhead notes were indecipherable 
- class material did not line up with homework or exams

Overall, this was a good survey course for biostatistics because it covers the fundamental concepts in statistics. The addition of the lab component made the class much more applicable to a professional setting, which I was very satisfied with.

This class overall is really organized and easy to follow. The computer labs adequately reflect the materials covered in the lectures. The SAS handouts were helpful on understanding difficult material. One way the class could improve is the SAS programming. It will be more helpful if we have more introduction to the SAS program and we could try our own code (as like the last lab) instead of solely copying the code from lab slides.
lots of work
I enjoyed the material, but I wish we had had discussion groups similar to Epi.

This is a good class to learn the basics of biostatistics and SAS. It was helpful that the lecture and the computer lab were at separate times. The exams were the right level of difficulty. My only suggestion for improvement is regarding the time the lecture was offered. It would be nice to have it later in the day. I think some students would be more engaged in the course since they would be fully awake with their brains already warmed up.
I thought this was a well organized course that covered material at a reasonable pace.
Learning SAS was definitely valuable
This course did not feel like an introductory course to biostatistics. As someone with no background in biostatistics, I felt like this course did not provide me with enough of an introduction.
clear

Strengths - walked away with practical software skills
Weaknesses - between the lab and lecture component, there was a lack of integration until the last few sessions

Overall, I loved how available Professor Claus and the TAs were for office hours and they did a great job at clarifying concepts that students didn't understand.  I also found the exams to be fair in terms of rigor and they only tested us on material that had been covered in class.  

My biggest critiques would be that:

1.  While the TAs and the professor were great at clarifying concepts during office hours they weren't often good about being responsive to email communication which sometimes made scheduling times to meet difficult if a student couldn't make the standard office hours.

2.  The projector approach used by Professor Clause can sometimes get confusing to follow along with and it might be better for the course to transition to a powerpoint presentation structure.
I wish we learned a better programming language than SAS. But overall the class was good.

The pace of the course should be slowed down a bit for the students who have no background in statistics. Or, statistics should be made as a pre-requisite for the program. This course DEFINITELY needs to be recorded and put online (similar to other courses) due to the way the instructor takes notes and does not use a presentation to teach.

Overall, the course was good.  It was a nice introduction to biostatistics, but some crucial ideas behind the statistics were not discussed.  Further, we were able in some cases to use two-tailed tests to make conclusions from one-tailed hypotheses, which I was previously taught is not something we could do.

I learned very little by actually attending lectures. Most of the material came from the book. The course gave me well-rounded coverage of introductory statistical analyses and tests as well as an introductory understanding to SAS programming, which is what I was hoping to get out of the class.
Although the labs and the homework assignments required a greater time commitment than other courses, it really allowed students to have the opportunity understand the material.

This course was a great introduction to statistics and was useful as a refresher for those who have not taken a course for several years.  It was helpful to have the SAS labs integrated in with the course so students could become familiar with the program.  I appreciated how the examples in the class and in the homework were tied back to health-related questions.
Excellent

I had a very hard time reading the notes that were hand written on the overhead projector during class. Typed notes supplemented by handwritten problems when necessary would have been much more helpful. Additionally, it would have been helpful if the lectures were recorded so that sections that were harder to understand could be played back while studying.
Good course overall. It could be improved a bit by using powerpoint (or another visual aid) in lecture, though.
She was helpful and clear most of the time. I think she jumped around a lot between writing on the slides and writing on handouts so that got confusing sometimes.

Dr. Claus was a great lecturer and her humor was very much appreciated, especially since this would be the first class of the day while many are still trying to wake up. She was great at addressing any questions or confusion that would come up during class. I do feel like the lectures (and the notes she would write out for us to follow along) were sometimes hard to follow. There were some parts that could have used a bit more elaboration. But, again, she was great at going back to it if we were confused. 

I do wish that the handouts were available earlier in the class; many of us would often have to get back out of our seats to the back of the classroom to get handouts right before class started.

The instructor is very knowledgeable but uses outdated teaching methods making it somewhat more difficult to see and learn from all locations in the auditorium classroom.  It is also difficult to make up any missed classes, as the hand-written notes are not always explanatory or easy to read.
great instructor, i do not like the way notes are presented in class. A little unclear

Great instructor. Her expectations of students are clear and the problems done in class and assigned for homework are representative of test material. Material is sometimes taught in a nonlinear fashion which can be hard to follow at times.
notes are really bad

Firstly, there is no question that Dr. Claus is brilliant. I don't think anyone doubts that she knows the material very well. However, I felt like her delivery of the material during class was lacking. Specifically, the pacing was off and the material was presented in a disorganized manner. The handwriting was also extremely hard to read, so if the instructor is comfortable, powerpoint slides may serve future classes better. Additionally, following the syllabus may mitigate some confusion people had. If we are doing chi squared tests in this week's problem set, cover chi squared tests before the due date. Cover it a week earlier so that people can ask questions.
Claus is a very good instructor, since she is very patient, also she taught each knowledge point with strong preparations.

Overall very good - Dr. Claus is good at clearly explaining complicated ideas. However, there were sometimes inconsistencies or mistakes made during lectures that wouldn't be caught or corrected until later, which could be confusing.

She's really good at explaining concepts. Sometimes when I read the signed textbook, things are still unclear but I always feel like my understanding is much better after attending lecture. She also sometimes talks about the practical applications of techniques in real life, which I appreciate.
Great sense of humor, very organized and methodical way of teaching so that her students understand.
I think she was a great professor.  Very clear.
Good, but sometimes skipped around in lecture topics and had very sloppy handwriting so it was hard to read and sometimes hard to follow too.

Professor Claus is helpful in answering questions in class. However, her handwritten class notes are not well organized and often difficult to read, which made reviewing class materials very difficult. Also, I feel that the teaching fellows were more reachable for questions  thanProf Claus.

Strengths:
Lots of Examples

Weaknesses:
If you couldn't keep up with notes in class the online copies that were uploaded were hard to read. Would have preferred powerpoint and paper for working out problems by hand.
Knowledgeable and nice.
Instructor did an overall good job teaching the course. The instructor was very helpful in office hours. Lectures could go off on unrelated tangents at times.
Teaching with an overhead project is not the best way especially when the instructor's handwriting is poor. However, the contents covered in the course were informative. Exams were fair.
be more open to powerpoint instead of overhead projector and make the class motes  tie in with whats expected on the hw and tests
She was really nice, but Dr. Claus' teaching approach was kind of all over the place and she wasn't very organized.
teacher was very kind as a person but as a teacher for biostatistics not so much

The instruction was poor.  The lectures lacked fluidity and coherence. I learned mostly from the book. When studying I never looked back at my notes because they were more confusing than helpful. It seemed like the lectures were unstructured and the notes were just stream of consciousness. I really liked Dr. Claus as a person but thought her instructing could use some work.
good

I found her to be helpful. There were times when her lecture formats were not as organized as I would have preferred, and using the projector and hand-written slides was especially difficult to follow if you weren't in class. Definitely had to be in class to understand what was going on.
Professor Claus has had a lot of teaching experience and her lectures always go smoothly. However, I have left class sometimes feeling like she didn't fully answer my questions.

Strengths:
+ Very knowledgeable about biostatistics
+ Cared about us learning the material

Weaknesses:
- Wrote on clear projector paper with permanent marker--not environmentally or economically friendly!
- Handwriting was sometimes messy, so could not interpret class notes
- Sometimes the book was better at explaining the topic than class

Dr. Claus clearly knows what she's talking about, and if you're alert and have done the reading, she's relatively easy to follow. Sometimes you get the impression that she's a little too smart to be teaching a basic level class, and it can be easy to get lost sometimes. Her method of writing on an overhead is both good and bad. It's nice to see the calculations being done as we talk about it, rather than trying to follow along on an already-typed slide. But they are impossible to decipher if you miss a class, and can be disjointed and not very clear.

Strengths: Expertise, patient, willing to answer questions, encouraged questions, repeated material, good timing for organizing lectures.

Weaknesses: Handwriting, final exam writing

Strengths: Dr. Clause always listened to students and was very attentive when someone raised their hand. She made it easy for students to ask questions in a large class setting.
Weakensses: In lecture, Dr. Clause went a little fast sometimes. One minute you would be writing down/copying what she wrote and the next, the information was gone.
Improvement: Go slower in lecture and pause before taking a slide off the projector.

strength- very knowledgable and patient with explaining content

weakness- not many, you did a great job of teaching the material
I REALLY LIKE Professor Claus' classes! Very clear, easy to follow, logical, and it is one of the best classes I've taken this semester, and I always looked forward to it!!

Dr. Claus is an amazing professor, and really an inspiration for all women looking to be involved in STEM. I thought she was very friendly and approachable, always willing to answer questions in class. She really broke statistics down in a way that made it accessible to people of all levels.
Professor Claus is very approachable and kind. She was always very warm and helpful during her office hours.

Super chill
Handwriting is impossible to read, so it's important to go to class because her notes are indecipherable

She was a patient and clear instructor for the most part. However, I do feel like the use of handouts could be improved. By switching back and forth between handouts and written note, it was hard to keep a clear record of what was going on and was difficult to interpret my notes outside of the class setting. More clearly connecting the SAS material with concepts in class without jumping back and forth between handout and written notes would have been helpful.

She was very approachable all semester, and explained things well during class itself. I feel like the problem sets and exams were challenging yet extremely fair, and provided opportunities for us to apply things we were learning in the classroom to more "real-life" examples like in the instances of grant writing and research.
I often left class more confused than when I walked in.

The class content and the instructor's teaching style is good, but the notes uploaded on Canvas can be more readable in case sometimes we are not able to attend the class. 

Maybe some quiz or exam on SAS script writing can be helpful in learning SAS. Recommend some more R teaching

The course very split between what we were learning in the book and how we were being taught in lecture. I think that this course could be dramatically improved through instruction that paralleled the chosen text.
Professor Claus is very intelligent. PowerPoints would be helpful because it is hard to read her handwriting sometimes
Dr. Claus is very intelligent and helpful and clearly cares about her students but is at sometimes disorganized and slightly hard to follow in class/in the notes posted after class.

Professor Claus was very considerate when we were learning difficult material and carefully walked us through step-by-step so everyone could follow along.  I never felt as though the rest of the class was rushing ahead of me in understanding; she taught in a way that could be understood by everyone.

Dr. Claus was fantastic during office hours. She was always willing to answer questions and was extremely approachable. I think it's rare that a professor is so willing to answer the most basic questions, in such a non-judgemental way. I know the questions that I was asking at the beginning of the semester must have been excruciating! 

I think that the classes were well structured,  but I think that some of the notetaking functions could be improved to help students review or understand the materials better. While I think that the notes taken in class were good for visualizing what we were learning and discussing, maybe a short outline of the class material would be a helpful complement!

She is very knowledgeable about the course material and presents topics in a clear and concise manner.  The one time I went to office hours to get help on the homework she did a very good job at answering my question.  At times her handwriting was difficult to go back and read again but there's not much she can do to change that.

I felt that many lectures were very disorganized-- the professor would start a problem, but wouldn't finish it before going on to something new. Or she would start by listing something out, but then go on a tangent before finishing the list, making my notes very difficult to follow logically. Office hours were very helpful though!
She should teach multiples ways of approaching single problems.

STRENGTH: She's really nice and friendly toward students
WEAKNESS: It's difficult to read her handwriting

Professor Claus is really nice to our questions. But I think to use PPT while teaching is easier for students to understand the class content. it is clearer than hand-writing and easier for reviewing.

She was nice. Sometime problems in class were answered in a very roundabout way which made it confusing to follow. Grading on exams seemed subjectives. Reviews always were fairly simple and then the tests were substantially harder.

Dr. Claus was a fair professor.  I appreciated how she provided real world applications that are more realistic to what our professional needs in statistics would be.  For example, we focused more on using SAS than on doing equations by hand as this is more realistic to what we will be doing as public health professionals.  We did learn how do do the math by hand, but we gained important SAS knowledge.  Dr. Claus understood that many of us do not come from a statistics background, and she started from the bottom with the basics to make sure that students could understand the material.

Professor Claus taught the course very well and was very responsive to students during lecture. However, her handwriting for notes was often difficult to discern and it made making notes, and reading those notes later, very difficult. I like that with handwritten notes she goes over the material more slowly and carefully (as PowerPoint is sometimes difficult to go over material while still allowing students to take notes), but the hand writing is difficult.

The instructor does a decent job in as far as teaching the important concepts is concerned. The handwritten slides uploaded on canvas are tough to be used as a resource since the handwriting is, many times, unreadable.

Overall, I am satisfied with the instructor.
Fantastic!

Prof. Claus has the strength to explain the content clearly and guide us through the learning from elementary level of statistics to more moderate level. However, sometimes her handwriting can be interesting to read. Moreover, please let us know when we have to use the materials provided in the previous lectures. It is not convenient to bring all the materials for class all the time.

I think that at times she had trouble answering questions in class and didn't really make an effort to understand questions. Overall though, she was a clear lecturer. Sometimes the lectures were a little scattered making them hard to follow, but overall they were clear.
A bit scattered in class. Final exam was extremely hard, but midterm was fair. Homework takes long

Strengths = The professor was very knowledgeable and approachable whenever anyone had questions and she didn't mind answering them. She explained things well.

Weaknesses = She handwrites her notes, which I really liked because I could follow along as she was talking and I could write my own notes, but sometimes it is impossible to read her handwriting. It is also difficult for students who missed a class to understand what occurred in lecture by just looking at her handwritten notes.
She is a great instructor and was able to break everything down well. Her handwriting was difficult to read at times.

Again, I think she could have slowed down in her explanation of concepts, but I very much appreciated how approachable and supportive she was of the students. I also appreciated the number of support resources she made available.
The instructor is patient and willing to offer help to everyone.

Dr. Claus is a great professor and instructor for this course. She makes the concepts and theories we learn seem easy in her concise teaching method. Great at answering student questions. My only comment would be to use multiple examples since some of the concepts are so similar, that I would get the often confused with each other. Knowing when to use which concept would be more helpful, and I think that could be achieved through more examples or extra materials handed out to students explaining it.
Should consider using other forms of technology to lecture.

Professor Claus is obviously brilliant and highly qualified. I do think that she has been doing this for a long time, so the basics come very naturally to her. For someone like myself with no prior stats background, it's tough for me to understand at times when she skips steps or assumes we remember things from previous lectures.
Dr. Claus was clear in her lectures and very helpful when I met with her in person. She seemed very understanding of beginners in this subject.
The instructor's handwriting is very hard to read, please use PPT in the future

Professor Claus is clearly very smart and experiences, but she is really disorganized during lectures. Her hand-written notes are almost impossible to make sense of afterward, but the SAS outputs are easy to follow. I wish her organization of files on canvas were easier to follow, and the grades for assignments really should be posted on canvas as part of standard protocol so that students can track their progress and grade instead of just making guesses.
Her handwriting is barely legible but that's her primary method of taking notes

Professor Claus is joyful - funny, kind, and welcoming. Her classes were interesting and I appreciated the time she took to go through the material. However, her notes were sometimes a bit unorganized, and it was difficult to follow along with the material in the more challenging units. Likewise, the problem sets were difficult (which is fine), and I don't know that we were always given the proper tools to know how to solve them (based on course notes).
It will be better for the instructor to use a ppt in the future.

Professor Claus is fantastic. She is clearly very, very knowledgeable and, as fas as my experience goes, accessible. My one comment would be that her lecturing style, which involves working through problems and theorems by hand on projector paper, is very difficult to follow along with after the fact, meaning that missing or coming late to lecture is detrimental.
Dr. Claus is generally good and approachable but her lectures can sometimes be a bit disorganized.
Professor Clause's lecturea are vey clear and detailed. She is also very patient to students' questions.
Amazing, caring professor. Brought biostats to life.

I think the course lacked good organization. The topics were organized by day, but then that was not reflected on the syllabus as specifically. Also, during lectures they were sometimes confusing because we would jump from one subject to another and then back, especially when answering student questions. I often couldn't hear the student and then the explanation wouldn't make sense. A thread was not so clear. This combined with the lack of structure in the textbook made it hard to understand how things worked together, or how topics built on eachother. The labs did help connect the dots a bit.  I think this class could have been a lot less difficult for me if I had understood where we were going with the material. Everything was a little too surface level, I think.
Clear although not too organized. Still made content easy to understand.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor was warm and friendly to students, and demonstrably knowledgeable. 
-- The professor clearly communicated expectations for how to navigate the course.
-- The professor made complex subjects seem less daunting by her way of communicating.
WEAKNESSES
-- The professor regularly asked questions during class, but they were generally rhetorical. I recommend asking a simple question, then instructing all students to vote with raised hands, or instructing please raise your hand if you have an answer. Then pause and count slowly to 15 while students brains kick into gear. That would hold us accountable to engage with the material.

Strengths: Very knowledgeable
Weaknesses: Did not present SAS coding in a way that made retention of material easy to understand; was not the most understanding when students asked questions or asked for help on content

- very hard to follow during class, in part because of handwriting
- problems by hand I learned entirely from book, class was useful only for interpreting SAS outputs

Dr. Claus is a phenomenal professor who is very good at illuminating difficult material in person. However, in a large classroom setting her classes were a little hard to follow at times mainly because her lecture notes were difficult to read. Other than that, I think she taught biostatistics very well.
Dr. Claus is a great instructor. She is nice in person and as a instructor. She is always willing to help and hopes we can succeed the  class.
She goes very quickly because there is a lot of information to cover

Prof. Claus is the pinnacle of academic achievement and I felt lucky to learn from her. However, I do think her way of teaching the material made it difficult to understand. I really liked Yasmin's lectures as they were clear, concise, and stuck with me. I would suggest creating powerpoints that are legible and easier to go back and review.
Professor Claus seems genuinely interested in the subject matter and the learning of her students.
Very knowledgeable and helpful to students; was not used to teaching style at first, but became accustomed by the end of the semester

I highly, highly recommend that the instructor change their way of notetaking. She wrote her notes on an overhead projector, which was extremely disorganized and difficult to read. Although she uploaded the notes to Canvas, they were unhelpful to go back and try to read. I highly recommend that the instructor instead prepare powerpoint slides. This would be much more clear.
she is really nice
Great! She can explain everything very clearly.

Professor Claus is an extremely empowering, motivating, and insightful professor.  She does a phenomenal job at helping to clarify concepts to students and puts a lot of effort into making sure that we're excelling.

My main critiques would be for her to be more responsive to email correspondence and for her to transition away from the projector approach to lecture as her handwriting is sometimes difficult to read.

The instructor was very knowledgeable of the subject matter but at times it seemed difficult for her to be able to break down the topics for students to understand. It would be EXTREMELY helpful if the instructor recorded the lectures or used PowerPoint (or some other presentation software) instead of free-hand, shortened lecture notes. It made it extremely difficult to look back on notes and understood what was covered.

Dr. Claus was a good professor, and was very knowledgeable about the subject of statistics.  However, she tended to move quickly over certain explanations that I think would have been important to emphasize.

The lectures conducted by the PhD candidate were informative, thorough, and effective. The lectures conducted by the instructor were disorganized, hard to follow, and impossible to refer to after the lecture. If the instructor's lectures were made into powerpoint, as the PhD candidates were, the lectures would be much more effective and informative to us in lecture as well as during exam and homework preparation.

Dr. Claus is energetic and an excellent professor.  She was able to clarify students questions during class and was helpful during her office hours.  My only suggestion is to convert some of the class material to PowerPoint to keep students organized.
Excellent
Often could not read handwriting.

I think this course gives a good framework for biostatistics. I definitely recommend taking it if you need a refresher on basic stats too. The homework can take a long time because they require both textbook and lab work but overall its manageable and graded fairly.
This course provided a great foundation for introductory biostatistics and SAS. I feel confident going into Biostats II after finishing this course.
This course requires self-directed learning but does provide a good foundation in statistics.

I would recommend taking it if he has not taken any biostats or any stats course. But redundant if had any stats experience even if had no experience with sas. Not worth taking, can learn sas independently and use his precious time at yale taking another interesting course
really hard final kind of want to cry because though I've done well on HW (92) and I received a C on the midterm I am scared I won't pass

I would recommend it because the material learned is definitely applicable to whatever you are studying (assuming you are studying biostats/epidemiology). It goes into a good enough degree of depth to understand fundamental statistical testing. It also gives you an idea of how biostats as a field might be, so you can use it as a metric for whether or not you want to take additional courses in this department. However, don't expect to master SAS or R while taking this. It's a brief introduction, and you will need to take additional courses to really test out your knowledge in either.
I strongly recommend this class to other students, since the knowledge of statistics I learned from this class is helpful, which I do believe that will help me understand biostatistics.

I would recommend this class if you've had no prior experience with statistics. I actually took this class to learn SAS and R but I felt like the R portion was really eclipsed by everything else. So I don't recommend it for learning programming; it's a little boring if you have already taken a statistics class before like I have
Yes, I would take this course if you want to review or learn the basics of statistics.

This is an introduction to Biostatistics. You learn mostly about SAS and a tiny bit about the theory behind the statistics. The lab sections are unhelpful. If you want to learn R instead of SAS, they say that you can, but you'd really have to go to office hours for someone to teach you because for the 9+ slides you get about how to do the SAS programs, you get 1 or maybe 2 if you are lucky. Don't miss lecture because the handwritten slides that are uploaded are hard to read.
Take it if you have to, or if you're invested in learning SAS.
The course was a good overview of basic statistics and left me well-prepared for future statistics course. Would recommend.

I would recommend this class even to those who have taken a statistic course previously. Unless a student knows how to use SAS and retains a good amount of knowledge in statistics, one would find this course very informative.
It's a requirement we all have to get through. Hopefully they pick a new teacher for it soon.
would not recommend unless if it was a requirement
would recommend since class is nice designed
I felt like this was an adequate overview of statistics.

This is a really good introduction to statistics, and I would recommend it above other introductory courses because of the SAS component. You will leave the class with a grasp of how to analyze statistical data in public health research.
If you can opt out, do it. The only additional thing you might not have learned in your earlier classes is SAS.

Not awful for a biostats class. The tests are relatively easy in terms of questions, but the grading is very very nitpicky (and seemingly arbitrary) so you'll still lose points (on the homework as well). Pretty important to go to every class, since she takes notes on an overhead sheet as she goes, and it's pretty impossible to decipher them if you weren't in class while they were being written. Big deal about the labs but you're never actually tested on writing any SAS code, so if you want to get good at it you'll have to be self motivating. Overall it wasn't nearly as awful as I imagined a biostats class would be, and Dr. Claus is sassy and intelligent.

This course requires a ton of work some weeks and barely any work other weeks. It depends whether or not homework is due on a certain week. The course is taught well, yet being a fast learner in class definitely is helpful since the class is fast-paced. I would recommend this class but would tell students that they need to be prepared and alert in class.
It helps to learn the basic statistic knowledge also show the SAS exercises.
I do recommend the course since it provides a good general introduction to statistics and the material is taught in a methodological and clear manner.
I would as it is so important and the instructor is so great and clear! Also, I'd like to learn python or R instead of SAS (that might be the only "complaint") I am truly happy with what I've learned
The class teaches sas not biostats...

Basic statistical methods, but taught in a way that it is applicable to a multitude of career paths within Public Health. Everything that an intro biostats course should be. 100% would recommend. Love that exams were open note/open book, because I think that's really how real life is.

It is a pre-requisite for most MPH students; if you have the option to waive the class I would since there is a lot of homework and the lab every week can get tedious with other classes and commitments.
Would recommend as a good foundation, plus it's a requirement for most people

This is an introduction to basic statistics as applied to real-world public health and clinical examples. It helps the student learn how to analyze primary literature that uses these concepts. I would recommend this class to a student who has not taken a significant amount of statistics before. Otherwise, the content may seem basic and repetitive.

Challenging, but overall beneficial in terms of how much it relates to other courses. It all greatly prepares us for a lot of real world challenges in analyzing and understanding public health related research.
This course was a waste of time. I wish I had waved out of it at the beginning of the semester with everyone else.
I would recommend this course because it gave me a good introduction to statistics upon which I can build. I would say, however, to expect to be teaching yourself for the majority of the course.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student as it sets a solid foundation in biostats. It is a fair amount of work but the expectations on students are realistic.
Excellent resource if you are looking to combine basic biostatistics and SAS basics.

I think it's a really fantastic foundation in statistics. I would highly recommend it and think that it was actually one of my favorite classes this fall. The help available and range of material makes it very interesting and accessible to many types of students.

This course was very beneficial for me as someone who had never taken a statistics course.  I left the course with a solid understanding of the statistics concepts necessary to understand in the field of public health.
I wish I had waived this course.
It's relatively easy, and should not require too much time outside of class. Helps familiarize you with SAS.
yes. it is a basic course

Course is a requirement unless you can test out. If you have to take another semester of biostat I would recommend not opting out, there is a lot of stuff that we learn that I learned differently than when I took biostat in undergrad, and there was a lot more coding that seemed more specific to this class than what I had previously learned (certain ways to do certain things). It's fine; seems fairly subjective and you can study for exams but it is open note/open book although the wording of the questions still makes this difficult. Use your TAs!! They are great and will definitely be an asset if you take this class.
Gain an understanding of SAS and its uses in public health while learning the statistics behind the programing.

Only commenting on the lab, the lab was helpful to practice and learn SAS to some extent, but if you are auditing the lab only you should be comfortable with the topics that everyone else is learning in lecture.

The course is useful to learn basic principles of statistics, but I feel the course could be enhanced if combined with epidemiology principles, as both courses cover similar subject material and it would be useful to apply statistical thinking with epidemiological approaches.
I would recommend this course as a good start for learning the basics of biostatistics.
Yeslearn a lot!
Yes, the bridge to almost all advanced class.
I am glad this introduction to biostatistics is provided to us, especially that if we learned similar content a few years ago and might have forgotten most of it.

I would say that it was a challenging and useful course. I would suggest that the student take advantage of TF and professor office hours in order to gain a better understanding of the content when needed.
Necessary learned a lot about SAS.
Yes I would recommend it because it helped me establish the foundational knowledge I needed in biostatistics.
They were all very helpful and they were very much in demand during office hours.
It is a good introductory biostatistics course and is a good way to learn SAS.
Yes, I would recommend this course to students with no prior biostats experience.

I think that if the student has a strong math background, it would be easy for them to grasp the material. I think better instruction needs to happen in SAS. We were just kind of told what code to put in without actually learning how to apply it. I don't think I came out of the class with the ability to write my own code for my own research study in the future.

I learned a great deal in the course and worked really hard on the homework and lab assignments. Much work and attention is needed for these assignments so best to start working on them weeks before they are due.

Strengths 
- The textbook is great and you really do come out with a solid basic understanding of biostatistics and the SAS program. Honestly just reading the book will give you a better understanding than going to lectures, though.

Weaknesses 
- Professor Claus is pretty disorganized and her in-class notes are impossible to read or make sense of afterward. 
- I wish the organization of files on canvas was easier to follow. The file naming system needs major work.
- The grades for assignments really should be posted on canvas as part of standard protocol so that students can track their progress and grade instead of just making guesses.
Helpful and totally relevant to what I will be doing in my career
N/A Placed out
This course is really important to catch up the basic knowledge for biostatistics, and it can also help you build your statistical thinking.
BIS 505a is, as the title suggests, an introduction course to biostatistics. You will learn the basics here, and you will learn them well.
This course teaches about how to analyze the data in a epidemiology study or other study.

It is a basic look at binomial analysis. It will be frustrating along the way, but it all links up in the end to be useful. It is frustrating that the thread of the course isn't so clear, but it is an important topic. I wish I had the skill to continue to 505b but I would be afraid of failing or losing time for other classes.
I would recommend as a refresher course not necessarily to learn everything if not seen before as it was easy to follow along only since I've taken stats before
I would recommend this course as a good first look at biostatistics in terms of mathematical concepts and practical application with statistics software.

The course is not something I would take voluntarily, as this was a requirement. I felt the volume of homework and labs was quite high and required additional time because the content was not presented in an easy to understand way during lecture.

This class is  more an introductory stat class to me. If you have taken some stat class in the past, you can consider to waive the class. However, it can be a great refresh to you. I knew most of the class topics before I took the class, but this class really taught me how to read SAS output and draw conclusions.
Good into course, lots of work
Waive out of it if you can.

This is a good introductory course to the statistics found in the field of public health and to the basics of SAS. I would recommend this to any students who wants to either learn for the first time or refresh their knowledge of introductory statistics. It is also a good class for someone with no experience in SAS looking to begin learning about the program. Both the statistics and the SAS classes are accessible to a student with on background in either, which is a strength of this course! You cover a lot of material in just one semester. Overall, I would recommend it to another students
Good introduction to biostats and SAS, relevant crossover with Epi and some other courses
Yes, it is not a very difficult course. If you do not have any background of statistics, this course will be a perfect course.

I think this class is great regardless of whether or not you've taken statistics before.  I technically could have placed out of the class but was glad I didn't since it was a great refresher of material I had learned in past stats classes and it introduced new material that only prepared me more for future quantitative courses at Yale.

With this course, you must dive right in. It would be helpful to have some kind of background in statistics. If you do not, you will  be teaching yourself much of the material. The instructor is very personable if you approach her with questions. Take advantage of office hours!

This course gave me an applicable background in simple introductory statistical processes and SAS coding. I would recommend it for anyone with little to no statistical background because all concepts are explained simply and in understandable terms for those with little experience.
The course was not difficult, but required more work than my other courses. I enjoyed this class, and think the evaluations were fair and helpful.

This course provides a great refresher on statistics for those who haven't taken a stat class in a while.  It helps students understand how statistics can be used to evaluate questions in many different health-related contexts.  The class is also a great introduction to SAS for those who have never used the program.
